description: Data summaries and descriptive statistics; introduction to a statistical computer package; Probability: distributions, expectation, variance, covariance, portfolios, central limit theorem; statistical inference of univariate data; Statistical inference for bivariate data: inference for intrinsically linear simple regression models. This course will have a business focus, but is not inappropriate for students in the college.
name: INTRO BUSINESS STAT

values.comments:
This course helps students to develop ideas for making decisions based on data. The following material is covered: data displays (including box plots, histograms, scatter plots), summary statistics (including mean, standard deviation), uncertainty and probability as limiting relative frequency, the normal distribution as a reference standard, and statistical estimation and tests. The final course grade is determined from regular homework, one midterm, and one final.

Students thought the course was both interesting and at the same time very fast-paced. As a result, the class could be challenging for those with no previous experience in Statistics.

One student described Professor Wyner as “easily the best lecturer I have had.” Another characterized him as “knowledgeable, intelligent, and enthusiastic.” Many described him with tremendous accolades, a tribute to his excellent teaching ability.

As for the difficulty of the course, many students felt that it was tougher than expected for an introductory course. The tests “were hard and required assumptions that were difficult to make at times.”

This course helps students to develop ideas for making decisions based on data. The following material is covered: data displays (including box plots, histograms, scatter plots), summary statistics (including mean, standard deviation), uncertainty and probability as limiting relative frequency, the normal distribution as a reference standard, and statistical estimation and tests. The final course grade is determined from regular homework, one midterm, and one final.

Students thought the course was both interesting and at the same time very fast-paced. As a result, the class could be challenging for those with no previous experience in Statistics.

Many students remarked on Professor Rakhlin’s enthusiasm, characterizing him as someone who stimulates student interest and makes dry courses lively. Students described him as “obviously brilliant” and “funny.”

As for the difficulty, many students felt that it was tougher than expected for an introductory course. The class was described as “very difficult at times.” One student also mentioned that the homeworks were “tedious and long.” Students also complained about the textbook for the course.
